author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Megan Specia
title: Memorial to Massacre Victims in Norway Divides Traumatized Community
description: A decade after 69 people were killed by a right-wing gunman at a youth camp, the construction of a memorial is at the center of a lawsuit.
content: OSLO — July 22, 2011, is seared into the national consciousness of Norway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Tiffany Hsu
title: 11 Journalists on Covering the Capitol Siege: ‘This Could Get Ugly’
description: Reporters who planned to watch a political ceremony were caught in a wave of turmoil.
content: Reporters knew before they arrived at the Capitol on Wednesday that there would be large protests in support of President Trump. But most expected the day’s main event to be the drama and ceremony of the nation’s leaders debating the ratification of the Electoral College vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the next president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Blight
title: How Trumpism May Endure
description: The Confederacy built a lasting myth of victory out of defeat. Trump and his followers may, too.
content: One hundred and fifty years after the emergence of the Confederate Lost Cause ideology, a new Lost Cause invaded the U.S. Capitol with the incitement of the president of the United States. Waving American, Confederate, Gadsden and, especially, Trump flags, Donald Trump’s loyalists desecrated the greatest symbolic edifice of America.Trumpism has already become a lethal Lost Cause. It does not quite have martyrs and a cult of the fallen in which to root its hopes and dreams. But it does have a self-destructive cult leader about to leave power in a defeat that has been transformed into a narrative of betrayal, resistance and a promise of political revitalization.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sweatshirt Seen at Capitol Revives Distressing Memories
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 9, 2021.
content: “I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. It really broke a taboo. I never would have believed that was possible from Americans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry, Mike McIntire and Matthew Rosenberg
title: ‘Our President Wants Us Here’: The Mob That Stormed the Capitol
description: They came from around the country with different affiliations — QAnon, Proud Boys, elected officials, everyday Americans — united by one allegiance.
content: It was the table setter for what would come, with nearly 2,000 people gathering in Washington on Tuesday evening for a “Rally to Save America.” Speaker after angry speaker stoked stolen-election conspiracy theories and name-checked sworn enemies: Democrats and weak Republicans, Communists and Satanists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: In Vaccine Geopolitics, a Great Game Played With Ukrainians’ Health
description: Blocked from obtaining vaccines from the United States, its putative ally, and taunted in Russian propaganda, Ukraine turned to China.
content: Lyudmyla Boiko’s family has already had a harrowing, and lethal, encounter with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Critchley
title: What Would David Bowie Do?
description: Five years after his death, the dystopian world that his music describes seems closer than ever. But maybe he can show us a way out of it.
content: Everything went to pieces after David Bowie died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Viral Capitol mob figures arrested and charged for involvement in the siege.
description: Authorities also arrested a well-known conspiracy theorist who entered the Capitol shirtless, wearing a fur headdress with horns.
content: A man who was photographed carrying the lectern of Speaker Nancy Pelosi during the raid on the U.S. Capitol this week and another who roamed through the halls of Congress while wearing a horned fur headdress have been arrested and charged, the Justice Department said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Louise Linton Has Made a Movie
description: Scoffed at for conspicuous consumption, the wife of the departing Treasury secretary sends herself up in a camp-tastic dark comedy, “Me You Madness.”
content: LOS ANGELES — It starts with spider sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip receive vaccinations in Britain.
description: Queen Elizabeth, 94, and Prince Philip, 99, were vaccinated at Windsor Castle, but it remains unclear which vaccine they received.
content: Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, received Covid-19 vaccines on Saturday, according to Buckingham Palace, a day after Britain approved a third vaccine and as the country faced one of its deadliest weeks since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: As Trump Reels, Fox News Has a Message for Viewers: Stick With Us
description: As allies abandon the president, his favorite network revives familiar villains for the Biden era. And the prospects for a Trump TV media venture are “greatly diminished.”
content: His president reeling, his cable network at a crossroads, Tucker Carlson began his show on Thursday night asking a question that has echoed for weeks among anchors and producers at Fox News: “What is life going to be like for us on Jan. 21?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Hawley Faces Blowback for Role in Challenging Election Results
description: The junior senator from Missouri drew widespread condemnation but defended his decision to object to Congress’s certification of the election results.
content: WASHINGTON — The day after Josh Hawley became the first Republican senator to say he would indulge President Trump’s demand that lawmakers try to overturn the election, a reporter asked if he thought the gambit would make him unpopular with his colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer
title: Democrats Are Determined to Pressure Biden to Investigate Trump
description: Wide segments of the party are eager to see investigations and prosecutions of President Trump and his allies, while President-elect Joseph Biden is taking a more measured approach.
content: WASHINGTON — Twelve years ago, when the last Democratic president took office, he did not seek broad inquiries into officials from the previous administration for their use of torture practices, or for domestic eavesdropping. Nor did he pursue prosecutions of Wall Street executives for crimes that led to the 2008 financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Michael Apted, Versatile Director Known for ‘Up’ Series, Dies at 79
description: His output included “Coal Miner’s Daughter” and a James Bond film. But he was best known for his long-running documentary series about life in Britain.
content: Michael Apted, a versatile director whose films were as varied as the James Bond picture “The World Is Not Enough” and the biographical dramas “Gorillas in the Mist” and “Coal Miner’s Daughter,” and who made his most lasting mark with the “Up” documentary series, which followed the lives of a group of British people in seven-year intervals for more than a half century, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Trump’s Legacy: Voters Who Reject Democracy and Any Politics but Their Own
description: The mob attack on the Capitol, and interviews with Trump voters this week, show that the president’s subversion of democratic values will have enduring influence within the Republican Party.
content: The sight of a violent mob inspired by President Trump smashing its way into the Capitol was more than just a shocking spectacle. It also highlighted one of the most dangerous parts of Mr. Trump’s legacy: the disbelief in democracy that has metastasized among many of his supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: A judge has blocked Trump’s sweeping restrictions on asylum applications.
description: The policy, set to take effect next week, would have closed the doors of the United States to most asylum seekers.
content: A federal judge on Friday blocked the Trump administration from implementing a rule, set to take effect next week, that would have closed the doors of the United States to most asylum seekers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: China’s New Rules Could Hit U.S. Firms and Send a Message to Biden
description: An order issued on Saturday empowers Beijing to tell companies to ignore U.S. restrictions and allows them to sue other businesses if they comply.
content: China fired back at the Trump administration on Saturday with new rules that would punish global companies for complying with Washington’s tightening restrictions on doing business with Chinese companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Rampage Weighs on Congressional Staff Members and Capitol Workers
description: The violence caused by a pro-Trump mob on Wednesday has shaken many who work at the Capitol. And some people of color say the law enforcement response reopened old wounds.
content: WASHINGTON — Some huddled in corners of the U.S. Capitol, texting loved ones. Others were glued to their televisions at home as their place of work was overrun by rioters who smashed windows, ravaged offices and tore down American flags, shocking the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: As Circle of Trump Aides Dwindles, a Few Plan to Stay to the End
description: More and more White House advisers are jumping off the ship, but Hope Hicks and others remain by President Trump’s side.
content: WASHINGTON — Hope Hicks was so close to President Trump that he heeded her advice last June to defy protesters and march across Lafayette Square for a photo op she staged to project an image of “toughness.” The plan backfired when the peaceful protesters had to be flushed from the square with flash grenades and chemical spray, but Ms. Hicks remained a valued adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Tracey Tully
title: He Dreamed of Being a Police Officer, Then Was Killed by a Pro-Trump Mob
description: The death of Brian Sicknick, a military veteran and experienced Capitol Police officer, amplified the tragedy of Wednesday’s riots and undermined President Trump’s pro-law-enforcement claims.
content: WASHINGTON — Brian Sicknick followed his Air National Guard unit to Saudi Arabia, Kyrgyzstan and a military base in his home state of New Jersey, all in the hopes of one day wearing a police uniform. It was a wish fulfilled more than 10 years ago when he joined the police department tasked with protecting the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: The facial-recognition app Clearview sees a spike in use after Capitol attack.
description: Law enforcement has used the app to identify perpetrators, Clearview AI’s C.E.O. said.
content: After the Capitol riot, Clearview AI, a facial-recognition app used by law enforcement, has seen a spike in use, said the company’s chief executive, Hoan Ton-That.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel and Ken Belson
title: Here’s What Happened in Saturday’s N.F.L. Wild-Card Games
description: Washington challenged Tom Brady’s Buccaneers behind an unlikely quarterback. The Rams rode the defense to upset the Seahawks, and the Bills held on to beat the Colts for their first playoff win in almost 25 years.
content: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers were supposed to steamroll the Washington Football Team on Saturday night. Ten-point favorites, the Buccaneers were led by Tom Brady, the N.F.L.’s most prolific playoff quarterback, and numerous offensive weapons, including Antonio Brown and Leonard Fournette. Washington barely won its division with a 7-9 record and were forced to start Taylor Heinicke, who began the season as a backup in the short-lived X.F.L., when quarterback Alex Smith was scratched because of an injured calf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Trainer Barred in New York and Other States for Giving Horse a Racist Name
description: On Twitter, the trainer, Eric Guillot, denied that the name was offensive, but he had directed it at a Black television analyst. The horse ended up with a new name.
content: The New York Racing Association on Saturday barred a prominent trainer from competitions on its circuit for changing the name of one of his horses to a racial slur and taunting a Black analyst for the horse racing network TVG.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Mutoh
title: He Was Going to Close the Family Diner. Then He Got a Sign.
description: Chris Panayiotou was lost without his father, but the remarkable gesture of a stranger helped him heal.
content: Chris Panayiotou, a burly man with a kind smile, was always known for his playful side. When Mr. Panayiotou wasn’t tending to the family business, the 30-year-old Gee Whiz Diner in Lower Manhattan, he loved to get together with his father to tinker with cars and computers, or build Legos with his sons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Confederate Battle Flag an Unnerving Sight in Capitol
description: It was “outrageous” to see a man carry the flag inside the Capitol, something not even Confederate soldiers were able to do during the Civil War, historians said.
content: A Muslim American college student said he had fought back tears when he saw the image of a Trump supporter carrying the Confederate battle flag through the halls of the Capitol on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Trump Loyalists Arrested and Charged With Involvement in Capitol Siege
description: A well-known conspiracy theorist who entered the Capitol shirtless, wearing a fur headdress with horns, was among those arrested.
content: A man who was photographed carrying the lectern of Speaker Nancy Pelosi during the rampage in the U.S. Capitol this week and another who roamed through the halls of Congress while wearing a horned fur headdress have been arrested and charged, the Justice Department said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Like Some Letters and Lines
description: Grab the Scrabble set! Trenton Charlson is here with a high-scoring Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I enjoy Trenton Charlson’s style so much. I feel like someone on “Wheel of Fortune” picking “J,” “Q” and “Z,” knowing that the strangest letters are the most certain to make an appearance; at the same time, I’m always delighted by how light and artifice-free his constructions are. He manages to lay on the zhuzh without resorting to words like zhuzh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: Can Donald Trump Survive Without Twitter?
description: We’re about to see if he can truly be de-platformed.
content: On Friday, Twitter permanently suspended Donald Trump’s account. According to the company, one of the tweets that sealed the deal was “President Trump’s statement that he will not be attending the inauguration” and its implication that the results of the 2020 election were not legitimate. After years of using the platform to spread lies and conspiracies, after countless tweets amplifying white supremacists and QAnon believers, and after attempting to provoke both North Korea and Iran, the justification feels a bit like getting Al Capone on tax evasion. And yet the damage is irrefutable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Options for Struggling Landlords Whose Tenants Can’t Pay the Rent
description: Critical eviction moratoriums don’t offer much relief for mom-and-pop landlords who still have to pay to keep their buildings operating.
content: Q: I own a two-family property in Brooklyn. One tenant hasn’t paid rent since March. I am losing considerable rental income on this large garden unit, and the tenants haven’t made any attempt to pay back rent or negotiate a move-out or payment plan. But I rely on these bills to pay mortgage, taxes and maintenance — I am not an institutional landlord with deep pockets who can weather this. Do I have any legal recourse? How can this go on for so long with no relief?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Parler Pitched Itself as Twitter Without Rules. Not Anymore, Apple and Google Said.
description: Google and Apple told Parler, a social network popular with far-right conservatives, that it must better police its users if it wants a place in their app stores.
content: Parler is one of the hottest apps in the world, a social network that has attracted millions of far-right conservatives over the past year with its hands-off approach to policing users’ posts. And with the news that President Trump had been kicked off Twitter and Facebook, Parler was the odds-on bet to be his next soapbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: In Capital, a G.O.P. Crisis. At the R.N.C. Meeting, a Trump Celebration.
description: Party members at a gathering of the Republican National Committee endorsed President Trump as the man to lead the party forward, ignoring the turmoil in Washington.
content: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla. — In Washington, Republicans were dealing with a burgeoning crisis in their ranks, with high-profile resignations and bitter infighting over how to deal with an erratic and isolated president. But at the Republican National Committee’s winter meeting on Friday, most party members were operating in a parallel universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: A ‘Super’ N.F.L. Playoff Weekend Is Missing Something. Can You Guess What?
description: No, not Tom Brady. He made it. But the pandemic is forcing teams to keep large numbers of fans away.
content: The N.F.L. playoffs are one of the biggest sporting obsessions in the United States, typically among the most-watched television programming of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hedrick Smith
title: Neil Sheehan Forced an American Reckoning
description: Working with the reporter who obtained the Pentagon Papers for The Times, I saw firsthand his moral fervor about the people’s right to know the truth.
content: WASHINGTON — “It looks like a coup,” Neil Sheehan said. “I’ll call Mordecai. He’ll know whose tanks those are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Can Twitter Legally Bar Trump? The First Amendment Says Yes
description: There are reasons to question the wisdom of recent actions by Twitter in barring President Trump from its site and Simon & Schuster in canceling the publication of Senator Josh Hawley’s book. But the First Amendment is on their side.
content: WASHINGTON — When Simon & Schuster canceled its plans this week to publish Senator Josh Hawley’s book, he called the action “a direct assault on the First Amendment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Derrick Evans, a West Virginia legislator who stormed the Capitol, has resigned.
description: Like many other members of the pro-Trump mob, Mr. Evans made no effort to conceal his involvement.
content: Derrick Evans, a member of the West Virginia House of Delegates, resigned on Saturday after participating in the storming of the United States Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez, Thomas Fuller and Mitch Smith
title: ‘Our New York Moment’: Southern California Reels as Virus Surges
description: In the coming days, Los Angeles County will reach a level where one in 10 residents has tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: LOS ANGELES — A sustained surge of coronavirus infections has locked Southern California in crisis, overwhelming intensive care wards, ambulance services, funeral homes and local officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Meena Harris, Building That Brand
description: Kamala Harris’s niece is building her own empire with statement T-shirts. Just don’t define her by her family.
content: Meena Harris, a lawyer and former tech executive, used to make statement T-shirts as a side job. Her most famous read, simply, “Phenomenal Woman.” (Perhaps you saw it on Instagram, worn by celebrities including Serena Williams, Lizzo, Ciara, Viola Davis, Laverne Cox and Eva Longoria.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlayne Hunter-Gault
title: I Desegregated the University of Georgia. History Is Still in the Making.
description: The duty to remember our country’s history belongs to all Americans.
content: Sixty years ago, I walked onto the campus of the University of Georgia along with my high school classmate Hamilton Holmes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: George W. Bush’s Childhood Home Eyed for National Park Service Inclusion
description: The home, in Midland, Texas, was part of a formative time in the shaping of the future president, historians said.
content: The 1,400-square-foot house in Midland, Texas, where former President George W. Bush spent part of his childhood is under consideration to become part of the national park system, the National Park Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats ready impeachment charge against Trump for inciting the mob. Some Republicans appear open to the idea.
description: Democrats laid the groundwork on Friday for impeaching President Trump a second time, as Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California threatened to bring him up on formal charges if he did not resign “immediately” over his role in inciting a violent mob attack on the Capitol this week.
content: Democrats laid the groundwork on Friday for impeaching President Trump a second time, as Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California threatened to bring him up on formal charges if he did not resign “immediately” over his role in inciting a violent mob attack on the Capitol this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katherine J. Wu
title: Biden Plans Coronavirus Vaccination Blitz After Inauguration
description: The incoming Biden administration plans to set up federally run mass vaccination sites and to release all government-held vials, rather than hold some back for second doses.
content: WASHINGTON — In a sharp break with the Trump administration, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. intends to release nearly all available doses of the coronavirus vaccine soon after he is inaugurated, rather than hold back millions of vials to guarantee second doses will be available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: With New Law, Sweden Gains Power to Impose Coronavirus Restrictions
description: Parliament has approved an emergency law allowing the government to place limits on public places, fine individuals and order businesses to close down.
content: Sweden, which has long shunned lockdowns and face mask orders as tools in fighting the coronavirus pandemic, has given its government power to act more forcefully to stem the spread of the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Fear Spreads in Minnesota Town as ‘Extremist Group’ Moves to Open Church
description: Many residents of Murdock, Minn., said they were horrified that an organization condemned by watchdogs as a white supremacist hate group would open a church. City leaders said they had little choice but to grant a permit.
content: Maria Barron came to rural Minnesota 10 years ago from Mexico so her husband could work in a nearby dairy farm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: An 11th-Hour Approval for Major Changes to Medicaid in Tennessee
description: The Trump administration’s move, which Biden could eventually reverse, would loosen program rules and cap the state’s funding as part of a block grant.
content: With 12 days to go, the Trump administration on Friday approved a long-held conservative goal: to issue a state’s Medicaid funding as a spending-capped block grant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Trump Made the Fantasy Real
description: The Capitol Hill riot tore the veil between the right’s dreamworld and reality.
content: I will be honest and say that I don’t know exactly how to interpret the surreal events that unfolded this week in Washington, D.C., when a mob inflamed by online memes and presidential fantasies rampaged through the halls of the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Chicago Students Return to School on Monday. Will Their Teachers?
description: The mayor and teachers’ union are locked in a bitter fight over whether to reopen classrooms in the nation’s third-largest district.
content: As 6,000 prekindergarten and special education students prepare to return to Chicago school buildings on Monday for the first time since March, a question looms: How many of their teachers will be there to greet them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. attorney’s office opens probe into deaths of Capitol Police officer and protester.
description: The U.S. attorney’s office in Washington is leading investigations into the deaths of a woman who entered the Capitol building with a crowd of rioters on Jan. 6 and an officer who was killed while trying to police the violent mob, according to Michael Sherwin, the office’s top prosecutor.
content: The U.S. attorney’s office in Washington is leading investigations into the deaths of a woman who entered the Capitol building with a crowd of rioters on Jan. 6 and an officer who was killed while trying to police the violent mob, according to Michael Sherwin, the office’s top prosecutor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, John Ismay and Hailey Fuchs
title: Man Who Broke Into Pelosi’s Office and Others Are Charged in Capitol Riot
description: Federal prosecutors also backed off their suggestion that President Trump could be investigated for inciting the violence.
content: WASHINGTON — A state lawmaker from West Virginia, a 70-year-old Alabamian armed with jars of gasoline and a man who broke into Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office and posed at a desk there were among those arrested after the storming of the Capitol, federal law enforcement officials announced on Friday as they promised an exhaustive investigation into the violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: Pelosi asked the Pentagon about preventing Trump from using the nuclear codes.
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday took the unprecedented step of asking the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff about “available precautions” to prevent President Trump from initiating military action abroad or using his sole authority to launch nuclear weapons in the last days of his term.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday took the unprecedented step of asking the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff about “available precautions” to prevent President Trump from initiating military action abroad or using his sole authority to launch nuclear weapons in the last days of his term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesian Jetliner Crashes Into the Sea After Takeoff, Carrying 62
description: The Boeing 737-500, a Sriwijaya Air flight, had taken off from Jakarta, the capital. Officials said they found body parts and possibly part of the wreckage.
content: BANGKOK — A passenger jet carrying more than 60 people crashed into the Java Sea on Saturday, minutes after taking off from the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, Indonesian officials said, bringing renewed attention to a nation long cursed by aviation disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: For Far-Right Movements, Ashli Babbitt Is Now a ‘Rallying Cry’
description: Far-right and white nationalist groups online are holding up Ms. Babbitt’s death as proof that they have been wronged.
content: — Seyward Darby, author of “Sisters in Hate: American Women on the Front Lines of White Nationalism,” referring to Ashli Babbitt
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Calls Coronavirus Vaccinations an Ethical Obligation
description: Saying he will be vaccinated himself next week, Francis described the refusal to get the vaccine as suicidal.
content: ROME — Pope Francis said he would be vaccinated against the coronavirus as early as next week, calling it a lifesaving, ethical obligation and the refusal to do so suicidal, according to remarks made to an Italian television news program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger, Mike Isaac and Maggie Astor
title: Trump's suspension from Twitter caps an online revolt against him.
description: Twitter said on Friday that it had permanently suspended President Trump from its service “due to the risk of further incitement for violence,” effectively cutting him off from his favorite method of communicating with the public and capping a series of actions by mainstream sites to limit his online reach.
content: Twitter said on Friday that it had permanently suspended President Trump from its service “due to the risk of further incitement for violence,” effectively cutting him off from his favorite method of communicating with the public and capping a series of actions by mainstream sites to limit his online reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: How Singapore Has Kept the Coronavirus Off Campus
description: Singapore’s three major universities have reported zero cases. Their secret: technology, tough penalties and students willing to comply.
content: SINGAPORE — Every day, the president of the National University of Singapore scans his online dashboard to see how crowded the cafeterias are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats Ready Impeachment Charge Against Trump for Inciting Capitol Mob
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi threatened decisive action against the president for his role in the insurrection against Congress if he refused to resign.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats laid the groundwork on Friday for impeaching President Trump a second time, as Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California threatened to bring him up on formal charges if he did not resign “immediately” over his role in inciting a violent mob attack on the Capitol this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un Vows to Boost North Korea’s Nuclear Capability as Leverage With Biden
description: But as he pledged to advance the country’s weaponry, the North Korean leader also said he did “not rule out diplomacy.”
content: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, vowed to advance his country’s nuclear capabilities, declaring that it will build land- and submarine-launched solid-fuel intercontinental ballistic missiles, as well as making its nuclear missiles smaller, lighter and more precise, the North’s state media reported on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: To Start a New Habit, Make It Easy
description: Removing obstacles makes it more likely you’ll achieve a new health goal. The 7-Day Well Challenge will show you how.
content: Whether your goal for the new year is to lose weight, start exercising or focus on self-care, ask yourself: How can I make this easier?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: A Week Into Full Brexit, the Pain for U.K. Businesses Has Arrived
description: As Britain adjusts to life outside of the European Union, businesses are contending with delays, service cancellations and piles of paperwork.
content: LONDON — Britain started 2021 in a new relationship with its biggest trade partner, and it has immediately brought a litany of headaches and lost business.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shrimp Creole Will Warm You Up
description: Make Vallery Lomas’s dish, or any of the most popular recipes this week.
content: This weekend make Vallery Lomas’s shrimp Creole (above), and read about Louisiana Creole cuisine. And check out our other most popular recipes of the week, including David Tanis’s creamy leek and parsnip soup or Desmond Tan and Kate Leahy’s coconut chicken curry, adapted be Genevieve Ko. Find more NYT Cooking recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Peter Eavis and Lauren Hirsch
title: Loyal to Trump for Years, Manufacturing Group Now Calls for His Removal
description: The National Association of Manufacturers’ growing frustration during the last year culminated with its call to invoke the 25th Amendment.
content: WASHINGTON — The National Association of Manufacturers, a powerhouse business lobbying group, welcomed President Trump to its annual meeting in September 2017. Its president, Jay Timmons, introduced Mr. Trump as “a true champion for our industry, who has fought for manufacturing since Day 1 of his presidency.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: What Our Stars Say About Us
description: Only a handful of soccer players attain what might be best described as mainstream cultural relevance. That kind of fame now comes with responsibility.
content: There are almost eight years between the photographs, but they seem to come not so much from different eras as from different worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Former officials warn Senate confirmations of Biden’s national security picks are needed quickly.
description: A bevy of top former national security officials from both parties have drafted an open letter urging the Senate to quickly confirm President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s national security team, warning of the need to have a fast transition of executive power after a week of chaos in the nation’s capital.
content: A bevy of top former national security officials from both parties have drafted an open letter urging the Senate to quickly confirm President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s national security team, warning of the need to have a fast transition of executive power after a week of chaos in the nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Ephrat Livni
title: When Business and Politics Mix, ‘Character Really Counts’
description: What should corporate leaders do in a moment like this?
content: A week in which some lawmakers tried to overturn an election and President Trump incited a mob to storm the Capitol ended with Twitter permanently suspending Mr. Trump’s account on Friday night, citing “the risk of further incitement of violence.” Around the same time, Parler, a social media platform with more permissive moderation that could serve as the president’s new digital soapbox, faced bans from Apple’s and Google’s app stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: In Michigan, a Dress Rehearsal for the Chaos at the Capitol on Wednesday
description: In April, armed protesters crowded into the State Capitol in Michigan. Frightened lawmakers saw echoes of that day in Wednesday’s deadly riot at the Capitol in Washington.
content: LANSING, Mich. — First came the “Unlock Michigan” protest. More than 1,000 cars, many draped with flags supporting President Trump, drove around the Michigan State Capitol, blaring their horns and decrying Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s coronavirus lockdown orders. Hundreds of others, many armed with military-style weapons, milled about on the lawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The G.O.P.’s New Distancing Policy
description: After years of excusing or ignoring President Trump’s most inflammatory rhetoric, many Republicans are backing away at the last minute.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Much of Pakistan Loses Power in Massive Blackout
description: The capital, Islamabad, and most major cities were affected in what was one of the biggest power failures to hit the country of 200 million people.
content: ISLAMABAD — Most of Pakistan, including the capital and many of its major cities, lost power early Sunday in one of the biggest blackouts to affect this country of more than 200 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jarrett J. Krosoczka
title: Gary Paulsen’s Real-Life Survival Guide
description: “Gone to the Woods” is a memoir so rife with childhood trauma he wrote it in the third person.
content: GONE TO THE WOODSSurviving a Lost ChildhoodBy Gary Paulsen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Trump and the Nation, a Final Test of Accountability
description: The push by Democrats to impeach the president for his role in inciting the attack on the Capitol underscores how American politics has been profoundly shaken in ways still hard to measure.
content: WASHINGTON — Barely 11 months after President Trump was acquitted in a momentous Senate trial, the nation now confronts the possibility of yet another impeachment battle in the twilight of his presidency, a final showdown that will test the boundaries of politics, accountability and the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Katie Benner
title: Georgia Officials Reveal Third Trump Call Seeking to Influence Election Results
description: In a December call, President Trump told a Georgia election investigator that the official would be a “national hero” for finding evidence of fraud. White House officials’ pressure on the federal prosecutor in Atlanta to resign was also revealed.
content: ATLANTA — More than a week before President Trump called Georgia’s secretary of state, pressuring him to “find” votes to help overturn his electoral loss, the president made another call, this one to a top Georgia election investigator, in which he asked the investigator to “find the fraud” in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Jim Tankersley, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katherine J. Wu
title: Biden pledges action on the pandemic and the economy.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday promised an accelerated response to a daunting and intensifying array of challenges as the economy showed new signs of weakness and the coronavirus pandemic killed more Americans than ever.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday promised an accelerated response to a daunting and intensifying array of challenges as the economy showed new signs of weakness and the coronavirus pandemic killed more Americans than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Oh, Fourpeat’s Sake!
description: Alex Bajcz schemes up a rhythmic Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Alex Bajcz, roughly pronounced “badges,” is one of those constructors who pops up with a gem, then vanishes for too long; this is his sixth construction since 2014, and his second Sunday. He’s a busy guy, an assistant professor of biology and environmental science at Drew University, in New Jersey, who’s currently researching fruiting plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: In Pulling Trump’s Megaphone, Twitter Shows Where Power Now Lies
description: The ability of a handful of people to control our public discourse has never been more obvious.
content: In the end, two billionaires from California did what legions of politicians, prosecutors and power brokers had tried and failed to do for years:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Claude Bolling, Jazzman With Crossover Appeal, Dies at 90
description: “Suite for Flute and Jazz Piano,” his 1975 collaboration with the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal, spent a decade on the classical album chart.
content: Claude Bolling, a jazz pianist and composer with remarkable crossover appeal whose 1975 album, “Suite for Flute and Jazz Piano,” spent more than 10 years on the Billboard classical album chart, died on Dec. 29 in Garches, a suburb of Paris. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By S. Kirk Walsh
title: How the Author of ‘Ragtime’ Taught an Aspiring Writer to Hear the Music
description: S. Kirk Walsh took a writing class with the novelist E.L. Doctorow and discovered a whole new world of sound.
content: I was born with “bad ears.” When I was a child, summertime swimming often turned into episodes of throbbing eardrums, and I would end up fetal-like on my bed, my hands cupped over my ears, rocking my body in hope that the movement would somehow diminish the insistent ache. My mom would heat up eardrops and slip the warm liquid down my inflamed ear chute with a dropper, creating temporary relief from the roar of pain. Tiny plastic cylinders were inserted into my ears on several occasions with the aim of draining the fluids that led to these bouts. Sometimes this worked. Other times it didn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Snyder
title: The American Abyss
description: A historian of fascism and political atrocity on Trump, the mob and what comes next.
content: When Donald Trump stood before his followers on Jan. 6 and urged them to march on the United States Capitol, he was doing what he had always done. He never took electoral democracy seriously nor accepted the legitimacy of its American version.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: Pressure Grows for States to Open Vaccines to More Groups of People
description: Some states are already expanding eligibility to people 65 and over, even though millions of people the C.D.C. recommends go first — health care workers and nursing home residents — have yet to get shots.
content: Just weeks into the country’s coronavirus vaccination effort, states have begun broadening access to the shots faster than planned, amid tremendous public demand and intense criticism about the pace of the rollout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Bittman
title: Why Your New Year’s Diet Is Doomed
description: It’s a struggle between you and the Big Food marketers who sell you junk. You’re set up to lose.
content: Nearly all of us will fail at our annual round of New Year’s resolutions, which historically are led by eating better and losing weight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump’s Capitol Offense
description: The presidency melts down, as Trump becomes too vile even for Twitter.
content: WASHINGTON — Even as a small child, I knew I was seeing something tremendous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Karan Deep Singh and Saumya Khandelwal
title: In the Cold and Rain, India’s Farmers Press Their Stand Against Modi
description: Protesters have created camps around Delhi that are virtual cities unto themselves, using donations and their own organizational skills to help their battle against new government farm policies.
content: NEW DELHI — Under a rain-slick tarpaulin, half a dozen elderly women bake roti on a wood-fired griddle — flattening dough, flipping browned bread from dawn until the sun retreats into Delhi’s evening smoke. Anyone who walks in gets served rice and cooked vegetables and, to wash it down, a cumin-flavored yogurt drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Facing Backlash, Republicans Confront Trump’s Effect on Their Party
description: In encounters with their constituents this week, Republican lawmakers have grappled with the consequences of their yearslong alliance with President Trump: an angry, misinformed base.
content: WASHINGTON — When a distraught constituent accosted her on Tuesday night at a restaurant in the nation’s capital, Representative Nancy Mace confronted an impossible task that sprang from President Trump’s false promises: getting them to understand why she and other Republicans in Congress could not simply overturn the results of the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A. President Seeks Delay on Vote to Let Students Profit From Fame
description: Facing pressure from the Justice Department, the N.C.A.A. president “strongly recommended” postponing a crucial decision, almost certainly extending a protracted debate.
content: The N.C.A.A., confronted with new scrutiny from the Justice Department, on Saturday all but abandoned plans for votes in the coming days that could have allowed student-athletes to profit off their fame, assuredly inflaming a debate that has drawn in governments across the country and convulsed the college sports industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Officers Who Handcuffed Black Family Won’t Be Charged, Prosecutors Say
description: The encounter with the Aurora, Colo., police in August was recorded on a widely shared video that showed four children lying on the ground in a parking lot, crying and screaming as several officers stood over them.
content: Prosecutors in Colorado said this week that they would not charge two police officers who drew their guns and handcuffed a Black family, including two girls, after suspecting them of riding in a stolen car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
title: A Hong Kong Website Gets Blocked, Raising Censorship Fears
description: Users of major mobile carriers can no longer access a service that detailed the personal information of police officers, a possible sign that the city is turning to tactics used in mainland China.
content: Hong Kong’s biggest mobile telecom companies appear to have severed access to a website that listed the personal information of police officers, setting off fears that the authorities may use a new national security law to adopt censorship tactics widely used in mainland China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Michael Cusack, 64, Dies; Helped Inspire the Special Olympics
description: An athlete with Down syndrome, he won numerous medals over nearly 40 years at an event that one admirer said would not have happened without him.
content: Michael Cusack, known as Moose, had Down syndrome. He also had a load of athletic talent. He played sports with his four sisters and neighbors on the South Side of Chicago in the 1960s. He also liked to masquerade as Batman or Superman, with a towel tied around his neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: Fred Piscop presents a variety of treatment options.
content: SPLIT DECISIONS — Today we have a tough cookie, in my opinion, although I freely admit that I’ve never conquered this flavor of variety puzzle. The setup is visually pleasing and intuitive: Given two pairs of parallel letters, find one other set of letters that can make two words, one with each of those parallel pairs. Solving rewards strategy, and I tend to thoughtlessly plop in possibilities and then paint myself into the various corners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Police officers who traveled to Washington are being investigated for connection to the Capitol melee.
description: Officials are investigating whether the off-duty officers played a role in the Capitol siege.
content: Police departments across the country have suspended officers or referred them to internal reviews for attending the events on Jan. 6 in Washington that devolved into an assault on the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Youmi Kim and Mike Ives
title: Asia’s Weather Was Frigid, but the Pictures Are Nice
description: In Seoul, Beijing and elsewhere, temperatures neared or exceeded record lows this week.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Seoul usually gets cold in winter, but not like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo, Selam Gebrekidan and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: As Coronavirus Mutates, the World Stumbles Again to Respond
description: A South African tip led to the discovery of mutations around the world. With infections skyrocketing, “it’s a race against time.”
content: DURBAN, South Africa — Doctors and nurses at a South African hospital group noticed an odd spike in the number of Covid-19 patients in their wards in late October. The government had slackened its lockdown grip, and springtime had brought more parties. But the numbers were growing too quickly to easily explain, prompting a distressing question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: The Myth of American Innocence
description: The Capitol attack shows the danger of forgetting America’s history.
content: The history of the United States is rife with episodes of political violence far bloodier and more destructive than the one President Trump incited at the Capitol on Wednesday. Nevertheless, ignorance of a grisly past well documented by historians like W.E.B. DuBois, John Hope Franklin and Richard Hofstadter was painfully evident in the aftermath of this week’s mob invasion of Congress. Talking heads queued up to tell the country again and again that the carnage was an aberration and “not who we are” as a people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Fauci Suggests Theaters Could Reopen ‘Some Time in the Fall’
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci told performing arts professionals that if the vaccination program was a success, performances could resume with relatively few restrictions.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the top infectious disease expert in the United States, told performing arts professionals at a virtual conference on Saturday that he believed that theaters and other venues could reopen “some time in the fall of 2021,” depending on the vaccination rollout, and suggested that audiences might still be required to wear masks for some time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna V. Smith
title: Indigenous Beadwork Flourishes on Instagram
description: Interest in Indigenous artistry has created an ecosystem of beadwork drops that sell out in minutes online.
content: Last year, after the museum that Tayler Gutierrez worked at in Salt Lake City closed temporarily because of the coronavirus, she turned to her beadwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Awe and Shock
description: How the world reacted to the Trumpist mob that sacked the heart of American democracy.
content: Around the world, the shock of Wednesday’s assault on Capitol Hill brought into sharp focus a question that has been smoldering for four years among America’s allies and adversaries. “And again the doubt,” wrote Emma Riverola in El Periódico de Catalunya, a Barcelona, Spain, daily, in painfully graphic terms. “Is this just a final burst of pus? Or has the infection spread, now threatening to cause a sepsis of the entire system?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Are We Stuck With Trump in the White House?
description: Let’s talk about options to remove him, and to change norms.
content: Do you remember Martin Gugino? He was the 75-year-old man who in June was peacefully supporting a Black Lives Matter protest in Buffalo when police officers shoved him to the ground, cracking his skull and damaging his brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: The Race to Lead Boston Is Suddenly Wide Open
description: The selection of Mayor Martin J. Walsh as labor secretary has shaken up the mayoral race in Boston, which has struggled with police reform and an extreme racial wealth gap.
content: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Bravery or Self-Preservation? Resignations of Trump Officials Draw Skepticism
description: The departures of cabinet secretaries and White House aides may put pressure on the president, but some see reputation management at work for officials whose jobs would end soon anyway.
content: WASHINGTON — In a city where people can strive for decades to land a plum government job, resignations on principle do not happen often and, when they do, often reverberate as selfless acts of valor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: A Question Hidden in the Platypus Genome: Are We the Weird Ones?
description: Researchers have produced the most comprehensive platypus genome yet, as well as that of another monotreme, an echidna.
content: When the British zoologist George Shaw first encountered a platypus specimen in 1799, he was so befuddled that he checked for stitches, thinking someone might be trying to trick him with a Frankencreature. It’s hard to blame him: What other animal has a rubbery bill, ankle spikes full of venom, luxurious fur that glows under black light and a tendency to lay eggs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Jacobsen
title: Were These the Fingerprints of a Terrorist?
description: Biometric data led President Trump to pardon an American soldier convicted of killing Afghan civilians. What if the data was wrong?
content: Four years ago this month, Donald Trump invited Sean Hannity to the White House for one of his first sit-down interviews as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
title: Facing Intensifying Crises, Biden Pledges Action to Address Economy and Pandemic
description: With job losses, record coronavirus numbers and politics in turmoil after the storming of the Capitol, the president-elect pressed for quick passage of a stimulus package to help struggling Americans.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday promised an accelerated response to a daunting and intensifying array of challenges as the economy showed new signs of weakness, the coronavirus pandemic killed more Americans than ever, and Congress weighed impeaching President Trump a second time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Quealy and Ben Shpigel
title: Four Reasons the N.F.L. Shattered Its Scoring Record in 2020
description: Fewer penalties, empty stadiums and more strategic decision-making helped power N.F.L. offenses to new heights in 2020.
content: Fewer penalties, empty stadiums and more strategic decision-making helped power N.F.L. offenses to new heights in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the draft of an article of impeachment against President Trump
description: A draft copy of an article of impeachment against President Trump charges him with “incitement of insurrection.”
content: A draft copy of an article of impeachment against President Trump charges him with “incitement of insurrection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Graham Swarmed by Trump Supporters at National Airport
description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, was accosted at Reagan National Airport by supporters of President Trump after he failed to uphold Mr. Trump’s false claims of election fraud.
content: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, was accosted at Reagan National Airport by supporters of President Trump after he failed to uphold Mr. Trump’s false claims of election fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 9, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 9, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about President Trump’s allies in media and politics after the storming of the National Capitol by a pro-Trump mob referred incorrectly to the police shooting of Jacob Blake. Mr. Blake was seriously injured; he did not die.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Joy for Brexit, and Mourning
description: “Britain has shrugged off the yoke of the E.U.,” one reader exults. “Britain truly cut off its nose to spite its face,” another writes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
